column4: how can I update the /dev/sda? files after deleting and creating new partitions with fdisk ?
you don't need to
why not? I can't see new partitions there
the device pseudo-files don't care about partition deletion or creation
not how it works.  What tool are you using to try to see the partitions?
ls
try:   sudo fdisk -l /dev/sda
fdisk -l shows them, but then I cannot mount them with 'mount'
(1) you need to use sudo with mount (in case you tried without sudo), and, (2) either you enter all the parameters correctly on the mount command line, or the correct parameters must be in /etc/fstab

fdisk -l /dev/sda shows '... /dev/sda8 2435 2435 8001 83 Linux'. But neither mkfs.ext3 nor mount can access /dev/sda8. mke2fs says: 'Could not stat /dev/sda8 -- No such file or directory'. I am running everything as root, and I can mount and umount other partitions.
do you get the same error message when you try to mount?
wait, if you can't make the file system, you can't mount it  :)
which program did you use to create the partition?
cfdisk
I'm groping here, but you might try deleting it and recreating it with fdisk instead of cfdisk.  That's not particularly logical but I've seen it work a few times.
I found the problem: Re-reading the partition table by the kernel fails, it is instructing me to reboot
rebooting won't fix it
try fdisk or sfdisk
I found the solution, running 'partprobe' after cfdisk did the trick
ok, weird though.  :)
the kernel couldn't reload the partition table it said 'resource busy'. I found this error message using fdisk, rather than cfdisk. partprobe (from the 'parted' package) allowed the reread
